com.clarkparsia.common.iterations
Interface Iteration<T,E extends java.lang.Throwable>

All Known Subinterfaces:
PeekingIteration<T,E>
All Known Implementing Classes:
AbstractIteration, ArrayIteration, DelegatingIteration, MultiIteration, TransformIteration
public interface Iteration<T,E extends java.lang.Throwable>

New iterator interface. Mimics Iterator in signature, but throws exceptions from its methods and its closeable. Intended for use in cases where the implementation is iterating over something such that calls to next() or hasNext() could result in an exception -- perhaps they are reading over streams or lazily performing a calculation. Similarly, the close() method is provide to signal that the iterator is no longer being used and that it is safe to free up any resources that it was using.

Since:
2.0
Version:
2.0
Author:
Michael Grove

next

T next()
       throws E extends java.lang.Throwable
Return the next element

Returns:
the next element
Throws:
E - if there is an error retrieving the next element
java.util.NoSuchElementException - if there are no more elements (hasNext() would return false in this case)
E extends java.lang.Throwable

hasNext

boolean hasNext()
                throws E extends java.lang.Throwable
Return whether or not there is another element in the iterator

Returns:
true if there is another element, false otherwise
Throws:
E - if there is an error while trying to see if there is another element
E extends java.lang.Throwable

close

void close()
           throws E extends java.lang.Throwable
Close the iterator. This signals that it is ok to free up any resources used by the implementation. It is expected, but not required, that subsequent calls to hasNext() or next() would fail and throw an exception, such as an IllegalStateException.

Throws:
E - if there is an exception while closing
E extends java.lang.Throwable
